He obtained his PhD and MSc degrees in Computer Science from Dalhousie University and Western University, Canada, respectively. His research intersects Human-Computer Interaction, Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Persuasive Computing to design, develop, and evaluate AI-driven, user-adaptive, and highly personalized technologies for social good across diverse domains including health and wellness. These technologies deliver evidence-based, highly personalized, and adaptive interventions in real-time while operationalizing appropriate behaviour change strategies to motivate, promote, and sustain desirable behaviours in individuals and groups.
